dialogueTree.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "The 'Suzerainty' box is heavy and s..."
dialogueTree.text: The 'Suzerainty' box is heavy and slightly awkward in your hands. You give it a light shake, and feel the pieces shift around inside.

links.title: You: "Read the rulebook."
links.text: Read the rulebook.

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "'Welcome to Suzerainty: A game of e..."
links.text: 'Welcome to Suzerainty: A game of economic strategy for the whole family!' The rulebook is sumptuously illustrated and thick as a Graadian novel.

links.title: You: "'Economic strategy'? More like rapa..."
links.text: 'Economic strategy'? More like rapacious plunder and exploitation.

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "The colourful illustrations depict..."
links.text: The colourful illustrations depict cheerful workers picking apricots, hauling marble sculptures out of crumbling temples, and harvesting a strange, magenta-leafed plant. Everyone is smiling.

links.title: Rhetoric: "You begin to suspect there may be a..."
links.text: You begin to suspect there may be a *political* agenda to this so-called 'family game'. Only one way to find out...

links.title: You: "Finally, a proper game to teach chi..."
links.text: Finally, a proper game to teach children about the importance of trade and the global economy.

links.title: You: "Finally, a proper game to teach Rev..."
links.text: Finally, a proper game to teach Revacholian children about their glorious history.

links.title: You: "Hmmm, this history seems *problemat..."
links.text: Hmmm, this history seems *problematic*, but it *is* important to teach children basic economic concepts.

links.title: You: "Keep reading."
links.text: Keep reading.

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "The instructions are opaque at firs..."
links.text: The instructions are opaque at first, and introduce many concepts you're not familiar with. Fortunately, there are many diagrams and examples throughout...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "You soon figure out the basic conce..."
links.text: You soon figure out the basic conceit: Each player represents an administrator for the *Suzerain of Revachol*. Your objective is to increase the suzerain's wealth and renown by accumulating *victory points*.

links.title: You: "How do you accumulate victory point..."
links.text: How do you accumulate victory points?

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "That's where the suzerain's vassals..."
links.text: That's where the suzerain's vassals come in. The game features four vassal nations, each one home to an economically important resource...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Each turn the player collects resou..."
links.text: Each turn the player collects resources from vassals where they've placed workers. They may then rearrange their workers, fulfil contracts for coin and bonuses, or build structures back in Revachol...

links.title: Reaction Speed: "As you leaf through the pages, your..."
links.text: As you leaf through the pages, your eye catches on a sidebar labelled 'ADVICE FOR BEGINNERS'.

links.title: You: "Read the advice."
links.text: Read the advice.

links.title: Reaction Speed: ""Remember, there are many paths to..."
links.text: "Remember, there are many paths to victory in *Suzerainty*, but successful players will find *one* strategy and commit to it wholeheartedly."

links.title: You: "Ignore it. Just tell me how the win..."
links.text: Ignore it. Just tell me how the winner is determined.

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "The actual scoring system appears i..."
links.text: The actual scoring system appears infinitely complex, with a series of tables and appendices required to compute each player's final victory point total. You skip that part for now.

links.title: Half Light: "Boring, boring, BORING. Tear up thi..."
links.text: Boring, boring, BORING. Tear up this rulebook and commit some old-school atrocities!

links.title: You: "How is the winner determined?"
links.text: How is the winner determined?

links.title: You: "Isn't there any way to invade or co..."
links.text: Isn't there any way to invade or commit atrocities or anything fun like that?

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Suzerainty is a family game. The on..."
links.text: Suzerainty is a family game. The only 'atrocities' you'll be committing are against the social standing of your rival administrators, as you bring in ever more resources and power for the suzerain. Speaking of...

links.title: You: "Fuck the suzerain, what about *my*..."
links.text: Fuck the suzerain, what about *my* wealth and renown?

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "There is no path to wealth and reno..."
links.text: There is no path to wealth and renown but through the suzerain. As one of the suzerain's trusted administrators, your very function is the glorification of Revachol...

links.title: You: "I've read enough. (Put the rulebook..."
links.text: I've read enough. (Put the rulebook away.)

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "You hold the open game box before y..."
links.text: You hold the open game box before you.

links.title: You: "Examine the components."
links.text: Examine the components.

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "You open up a number of pouches con..."
links.text: You open up a number of pouches containing wooden tokens. There are also several punchboards with other cardboard components that will need to be punched out before you can play.

links.title: You: "Punch out the cardboard pieces, one..."
links.text: Punch out the cardboard pieces, one by one.

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Each cardboard token makes a satisf..."
links.text: Each cardboard token makes a satisfying *chhhk* as you pop it out. Soon a neat pile of cardboard coins and counters has accumulated before you.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""What, you're not going to offer to..."
links.text: "What, you're not going to offer to let *me* punch any of them out?"

links.title: You: "Check out the wooden tokens."
links.text: Check out the wooden tokens.

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "In addition to the worker and build..."
links.text: In addition to the worker and building tokens used by each player, there are also several piles of colourful resource tokens, each representing one of the game's four principal resources...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "From the Empire of Safre: orange ap..."
links.text: From the Empire of Safre: orange apricot tokens. From Ile Marat (the ancestral name of Iilmaraa): gray marble block tokens. From the Semenine Islands: white sacks of sugar tokens. And from Supramundi and Saramiriza: magenta tokens for unprocessed cocaine leaves.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Oh, those are nice." The lieutenan..."
links.text: "Oh, those are nice." The lieutenant picks up a sugar token and admires it.

links.title: You: "Put the components away."
links.text: Put the components away.

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "It's a shame there's no one for you..."
links.text: It's a shame there's no one for you to play with.

links.title: You: ""Hey, Kim, wanna play?""
links.text: "Hey, Kim, wanna play?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant looks over the ruleb..."
links.text: The lieutenant looks over the rulebook before he sees something that makes his eyes go wide...

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Holy shit, the average playing tim..."
links.text: "Holy shit, the average playing time for this game is one to *six* hours..."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""I'm not sure we can afford to set..."
links.text: "I'm not sure we can afford to set aside *that* kind of time for a *game*."

links.title: Empathy: "So he says, but his gaze lingers a..."
links.text: So he says, but his gaze lingers a moment longer on the rulebook than is strictly necessary. He could *make* time, if he really wanted to.

links.title: You: "Pick up where you left off."
links.text: Pick up where you left off.

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "It takes a while, but you and the l..."
links.text: It takes a while, but you and the lieutenant manage to put everything more or less where it was...

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""As I recall, it was your turn, det..."
links.text: "As I recall, it was your turn, detective."

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "The endgame is upon you. What will..."
links.text: The endgame is upon you. What will be your crowning achievement as the suzerain's territorial administrator?

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "You could continue your efforts to..."
links.text: You could continue your efforts to win the hearts of your worker tokens by building the rarely attempted *public education system* for your territories...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Alternatively you could actually tr..."
links.text: Alternatively you could actually try to win the game by building the extremely valuable *victory column* in Revachol or by crushing the lieutenant in a devastating *trade war*...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "The choice is yours."
links.text: The choice is yours.

links.title: You: ""For almighty Revachol!" (Go for th..."
links.text: "For almighty Revachol!" (Go for the victory column.)

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Using the substantial coins and res..."
links.text: Using the substantial coins and resources you've accumulated from diligently fulfilling contracts and constructing trade routes, you spend your final turns constructing the ultimate structure in the game, the Revacholian *victory column*...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "With a triumphant flourish, you rem..."
links.text: With a triumphant flourish, you remove a rectangular token from one of the satchels and place it in the centre of the board...

links.title: You: ""Behold my vast accomplishments.""
links.text: "Behold my vast accomplishments."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""They're nice tokens, yes. Very imp..."
links.text: "They're nice tokens, yes. Very impressive..."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Now, let's tally up the scores, sh..."
links.text: "Now, let's tally up the scores, shall we?"

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Computing the final scores is almos..."
links.text: Computing the final scores is almost a game unto itself. You each spend an inordinate amount of time making stacks of coins, consulting tables, and struggling with basic addition and multiplication...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "After double- and then triple-check..."
links.text: After double- and then triple-checking your maths, you have your final score...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Thirty-five victory points! The suz..."
links.text: Thirty-five victory points! The suzerain will be extremely pleased.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant looks up from his ta..."
links.text: The lieutenant looks up from his tabulations. "I've got 26 points," he says, slightly disappointed...

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Looks like you won convincingly......"
links.text: "Looks like you won convincingly... well played, detective."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Now, let's clean up and get back t..."
links.text: "Now, let's clean up and get back to work."

links.title: You: ""Hmmm, this feels strangely anti-cl..."
links.text: "Hmmm, this feels strangely anti-climactic."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant sighs. "That's the p..."
links.text: The lieutenant sighs. "That's the problem with certain games. At some point they just *end*, as though no one expected the players to make it that far..."

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Building the ultimate structure req..."
links.text: Building the ultimate structure requires diligent economic planning, which you completely failed to do...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Rather than build a glorious monume..."
links.text: Rather than build a glorious monument to Revachol's economic superiority, you have to settle for a handful of post offices and school for the blind.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""A risky gambit, detective. Sorry i..."
links.text: "A risky gambit, detective. Sorry it didn't pay off."

links.title: You: ""This dumb game is rigged, rigged I..."
links.text: "This dumb game is rigged, rigged I say!"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Don't be a sore loser, detective...."
links.text: "Don't be a sore loser, detective. Your moves were your own..."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Now, let's tally up the scores, sh..."
links.text: "Now, let's tally up the scores, shall we?"

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Computing the final scores is almos..."
links.text: Computing the final scores is almost a game unto itself. You each spend an inordinate amount of time making stacks of coins, consulting tables, and struggling with basic addition and multiplication...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "After double- and then triple-check..."
links.text: After double- and then triple-checking your maths, you have your final score...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Fifteen victory points. The suzerai..."
links.text: Fifteen victory points. The suzerain will not be impressed.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant looks up from his ta..."
links.text: The lieutenant looks up from his tabulations. "I've got 26 points," he says, a barely contained smile breaking out across his face...

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Don't be glum, detective. There's..."
links.text: "Don't be glum, detective. There's always next time. Figuratively, I mean. There's no way we have time to play this game again..."

links.title: You: ""Guess I should have gone with a mo..."
links.text: "Guess I should have gone with a more consistent strategy."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""That might have helped, yes...""
links.text: "That might have helped, yes..."

links.title: You: ""It's on, Kim." (Launch a trade war..."
links.text: "It's on, Kim." (Launch a trade war.)

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant nods gravely as you..."
links.text: The lieutenant nods gravely as you erect tariffs against his apricots and sugar. This is going to get ugly...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "With every turn tariffs are raised,..."
links.text: With every turn tariffs are raised, until neither you nor the lieutenant are producing any income or generating resources for the suzerain...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "With your army of cheap, not-cocain..."
links.text: With your army of cheap, not-cocaine-addicted labour, you're able to survive the tit-for-tat of the trade war, though it leaves both your and the lieutenant's economies worse-off than before...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Soon the entire board is a field of..."
links.text: Soon the entire board is a field of economic carnage. Worker tokens lie strewn across the board, which is also bereft of valuable resources.

links.title: You: ""I hope you learned your lesson, Ki..."
links.text: "I hope you learned your lesson, Kim."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""I have no idea what 'lesson' you t..."
links.text: "I have no idea what 'lesson' you think you taught me. Somehow I don't think this is going to work out well for *either* of us..."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Let's tally up the scores, shall w..."
links.text: "Let's tally up the scores, shall we?"

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Computing the final scores is almos..."
links.text: Computing the final scores is almost a game unto itself. You each spend an inordinate amount of time making stacks of coins, consulting tables, and struggling with basic addition and multiplication...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "After double- and then triple-check..."
links.text: After double- and then triple-checking your maths, you have your final score...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Fifteen victory points. Whether you..."
links.text: Fifteen victory points. Whether you win or not, the suzerain is unlikely to be pleased at the loss to productivity caused by his subordinates' shenanigans.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant looks up from his ta..."
links.text: The lieutenant looks up from his tabulations. "I've got 15 points," he says...

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""A tie," he says, with evident irri..."
links.text: "A tie," he says, with evident irritation. "Well, I suppose that's what we deserve for trashing the suzerain's economy. Good game, detective."

links.title: You: ""Hmmm, that wasn't very productive..."
links.text: "Hmmm, that wasn't very productive for *either* of us, was it?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""No, not at all. I suspect this is..."
links.text: "No, not at all. I suspect this is going to be a rather *low-scoring* game..."

links.title: You: ""What happens now?""
links.text: "What happens now?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Now we find out what's left of our..."
links.text: "Now we find out what's left of our economies..."

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Even in the best of cases it's impo..."
links.text: Even in the best of cases it's impossible to really "win" a trade war. But this is far from the best case, and the lieutenant's apricot-powered economic engine crushes yours...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Soon your coffers are empty and the..."
links.text: Soon your coffers are empty and the map lies strewn with your worker tokens.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""I hope you learned your lesson," t..."
links.text: "I hope you learned your lesson," the lieutenant says with a sharp smile.

links.title: You: ""Yeah, never get involved in a trad..."
links.text: "Yeah, never get involved in a trade war in Insulinde."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Never fuck with Kim Kitsuragi.""
links.text: "Never fuck with Kim Kitsuragi."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Now, let's tally up the scores, sh..."
links.text: "Now, let's tally up the scores, shall we?"

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Computing the final scores is almos..."
links.text: Computing the final scores is almost a game unto itself. You each spend an inordinate amount of time making stacks of coins, consulting tables, and struggling with basic addition and multiplication...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "After double- and then triple-check..."
links.text: After double- and then triple-checking your maths, you have your final score...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Negative five victory points. You'l..."
links.text: Negative five victory points. You'll be lucky if the suzerain doesn't have your whole family executed for such a pitiful performance.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant looks up from his ta..."
links.text: The lieutenant looks up from his tabulations. "I've got 15 points," he says with a slight smirk on his face...

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Don't look too glum, detective. Th..."
links.text: "Don't look too glum, detective. There's always next time. Figuratively, I mean. There's no way we have time to play this game again..."

links.title: You: ""Yeah, never play board games.""
links.text: "Yeah, never play board games."

links.title: You: "Build a public education system for..."
links.text: Build a public education system for your workers.

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Your commitment to doing right by y..."
links.text: Your commitment to doing right by your workers pays off and you manage to construct the rarely attempted *public education system*. You truly have the best-educated worker tokens in the entire world...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Unfortunately, you were sent to the..."
links.text: Unfortunately, you were sent to the territories to produce raw resources, not overly educated second-class citizens. If anything, this might *negatively* impact your final score.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""See? I warned you investing in you..."
links.text: "See? I warned you investing in your workers wasn't going to pay off."

links.title: You: ""You taught me that points are arbi..."
links.text: "You taught me that points are arbitrary. I decided to play the game how I wanted instead."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant opens his mouth as i..."
links.text: The lieutenant opens his mouth as if to issue a blistering retort, then hesitates...

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""You know, detective, there's... so..."
links.text: "You know, detective, there's... something *admirable* about that, in its own way..."

links.title: You: ""My worker tokens have a right to a..."
links.text: "My worker tokens have a right to an education, Kim."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Noble as that sentiment may be, it..."
links.text: "Noble as that sentiment may be, it's not exactly a *winning* strategy in a game that revolves around resource extraction and exploitation..."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Now, let's tally up the scores, sh..."
links.text: "Now, let's tally up the scores, shall we?"

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Computing the final scores is almos..."
links.text: Computing the final scores is almost a game unto itself. You each spend an inordinate amount of time making stacks of coins, consulting tables, and struggling with basic addition and multiplication...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "After double- and then triple-check..."
links.text: After double- and then triple-checking your maths, you have your final score...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Two points. Though you're beloved b..."
links.text: Two points. Though you're beloved by your well-educated worker tokens, the suzerain is immensely displeased, and recalls you from your post.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant looks up from his ta..."
links.text: The lieutenant looks up from his tabulations. "I've got 20 points," he says with measured pride...

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Hey, at least you went out playing..."
links.text: "Hey, at least you went out playing the game how you wanted. There's something to be said for that."

links.title: You: ""Can I go back and do my turn over?""
links.text: "Can I go back and do my turn over?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""A little late for that, I think...""
links.text: "A little late for that, I think..."

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "There's a reason very few players e..."
links.text: There's a reason very few players ever attempt to built a public education system for their worker tokens: It's extremely expensive and never pays off, by design...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Your boondoggle nearly bankrupts th..."
links.text: Your boondoggle nearly bankrupts the suzerain's treasury and you suffer a significant penalty to your final score...

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Ouch," the lieutenant says, cringi..."
links.text: "Ouch," the lieutenant says, cringing at your spectacular failure.

links.title: You: ""You taught me that points are arbi..."
links.text: "You taught me that points are arbitrary. I decided to play the game how I wanted instead."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant opens his mouth as i..."
links.text: The lieutenant opens his mouth as if to issue a blistering retort, then hesitates...

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""You know, detective, there's... so..."
links.text: "You know, detective, there's... something *admirable* about that, in its own way..."

links.title: You: ""This stupid game is rigged.""
links.text: "This stupid game is rigged."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Come on, detective, you knew the r..."
links.text: "Come on, detective, you knew the rules of the game going in..."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Now, let's tally up the scores, sh..."
links.text: "Now, let's tally up the scores, shall we?"

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Computing the final scores is almos..."
links.text: Computing the final scores is almost a game unto itself. You each spend an inordinate amount of time making stacks of coins, consulting tables, and struggling with basic addition and multiplication...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "After double- and then triple-check..."
links.text: After double- and then triple-checking your maths, you have your final score...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Negative five victory points. You'l..."
links.text: Negative five victory points. You'll be lucky if the suzerain doesn't have your whole family executed for such a pitiful performance.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant looks up from his ta..."
links.text: The lieutenant looks up from his tabulations. "I've got 20 points," he says, slightly embarrassed at the point differential...

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Well, there's always next time. Fi..."
links.text: "Well, there's always next time. Figuratively, I mean. There's no way we have time to play this game again..."

links.title: You: ""Huh, maybe I should have pursued a..."
links.text: "Huh, maybe I should have pursued a different strategy."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""That might have been a good idea,..."
links.text: "That might have been a good idea, yes..."

links.title: You: ""I'm bored with this. Let's finish..."
links.text: "I'm bored with this. Let's finish the game later."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""C'mon, detective. This is the endg..."
links.text: "C'mon, detective. This is the endgame! Let's just finish up quickly."

links.title: You: ""Okay, let's finish up.""
links.text: "Okay, let's finish up."

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "The endgame is upon you. What will..."
links.text: The endgame is upon you. What will be your crowning achievement as the suzerain's territorial administrator?

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "You could attempt to build the migh..."
links.text: You could attempt to build the mighty *victory column* structure, or launch a *trade war* against the lieutenant, or spend everything to build a *public education system* for your worker tokens...

links.title: You: ""Nope, I'm done." (Start putting th..."
links.text: "Nope, I'm done." (Start putting the pieces away.)

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""As I recall, it was your turn, det..."
links.text: "As I recall, it was your turn, detective."

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Glancing over the board, you see se..."
links.text: Glancing over the board, you see several possible strategies: Pressing more workers into service would increase your economic output and help you survive a possible conflict with the lieutenant, or you could ignore your labour supply and focus on fulfilling contracts for points and resources...

links.title: Rhetoric: "Those aren't your *only* options."
links.text: Those aren't your *only* options.

links.title: Rhetoric: "You could also show your workers ho..."
links.text: You could also show your workers how much you appreciate them by *investing* some of that wealth in them. After all, they're the ones *producing* wealth for the suzerain.

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Well, sure, you *can* do that. It's..."
links.text: Well, sure, you *can* do that. It's just not a terribly *effective* strategy. But then, it's up to you...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "What do you do?"
links.text: What do you do?

links.title: You: "Invest in your existing workers."
links.text: Invest in your existing workers.

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "To the lieutenant's puzzlement, you..."
links.text: To the lieutenant's puzzlement, you spend several turns building various improvements to your territorial infrastructure...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Soon your workers have access to cl..."
links.text: Soon your workers have access to clean water, paved roads, and basic hobbies. In return they produce... one extra resource per turn.

links.title: You: "Gaze on your workers like a benevol..."
links.text: Gaze on your workers like a benevolent parent.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Hmmm, too bad investing in your wo..."
links.text: "Hmmm, too bad investing in your workers just isn't worth many points."

links.title: You: ""What do you mean?""
links.text: "What do you mean?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Take a look at the scoring tables..."
links.text: "Take a look at the scoring tables in the back..." The lieutenant turns to one of those appendices you skipped over earlier...

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""You see in Table 8c that investing..."
links.text: "You see in Table 8c that investing in territorial infrastructure multiplies your final victory point total by 1x, which is to say, not at all, whereas erecting monuments in Revachol gives you a multiplier of *5x*..."

links.title: You: ""So you're saying the values of the..."
links.text: "So you're saying the values of the ruling class are completely divorced from the well-being of the people who generate their wealth?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Yes, precisely.""
links.text: "Yes, precisely."

links.title: Rhetoric: "Nonsense. Remember what the lieuten..."
links.text: Nonsense. Remember what the lieutenant said? If points are arbitrary, who cares about *winning*? You should reject their system and just play how you want.

links.title: You: ""So you're saying I should treat my..."
links.text: "So you're saying I should treat my workers like disposable labour instead?"

links.title: You: ""So you're saying I fucked up?""
links.text: "So you're saying I fucked up?"

links.title: You: "Grimace at them for not working har..."
links.text: Grimace at them for not working harder.

links.title: You: "Press more workers into service."
links.text: Press more workers into service.

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Using your powers of 'persuasion',..."
links.text: Using your powers of 'persuasion', you 'convince' more workers to join your cause...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "After several turns your worker tok..."
links.text: After several turns your worker tokens greatly outnumber the lieutenant's. A vast army of expendable labour is at your command.

links.title: You: "Gaze on your workers like a harsh,..."
links.text: Gaze on your workers like a harsh, but proud, deity.

links.title: You: "Take pity on their miserable lives."
links.text: Take pity on their miserable lives.

links.title: You: "Focus on fulfilling contracts."
links.text: Focus on fulfilling contracts.

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Who cares about workers and territo..."
links.text: Who cares about workers and territories when the real action is in Revachol? You spend your turns fulfilling contracts for sweet coins and one-time bonuses.

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "After several turns you have a neat..."
links.text: After several turns you have a neat pile of cardboard coins and several units of archaeological treasure, which you trade in to build... a *museum*...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "You place a cylindrical piece of wo..."
links.text: You place a cylindrical piece of wood on the Revachol section in the middle of the board. It's meant to stand in for a beautifully adorned edifice filled with ancient wonders.

links.title: Encyclopedia: "Interestingly, this is more or less..."
links.text: Interestingly, this is more or less what happened in real life as well. To this day, if Iilmaraans want to see their nation's priceless treasures they have to visit Revachol or Gottwald or Sur-la-Clef.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Well played, detective. That museu..."
links.text: "Well played, detective. That museum is worth three victory points..."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "Now it's the lieutenant's turn to r..."
links.text: Now it's the lieutenant's turn to respond. He moves aggressively onto the Safre territory. Soon his workers are producing a steady supply of extremely valuable *apricots*...

links.title: Half Light: "How can you let the lieutenant *dom..."
links.text: How can you let the lieutenant *dominate* you like that? You need to hit back, and *hard*!

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "For several turns you struggle to r..."
links.text: For several turns you struggle to respond to the lieutenant's burgeoning apricot empire. Eventually you relocate the majority of your workers to Supramundi and Saramiriza, where they begin producing a bumper crop of cocaine tokens...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "You draw a new contract card. Accor..."
links.text: You draw a new contract card. According to the text, there's an aristocrat willing to trade a large supply of cocaine for a number of coins and access to a rare bonus: amplified music, worth *seven victory points*...

links.title: Electrochemistry: "Oh, yeah, baby. Cocaine and rock mu..."
links.text: Oh, yeah, baby. Cocaine and rock music go together like... cocaine and rock music.

links.title: Encyclopedia: "You know, this isn't *unlike* the s..."
links.text: You know, this isn't *unlike* the situation the historical Revacholian suzerainty faced in Safre in the middle of the last century...

links.title: You: "Tell me more."
links.text: Tell me more.

links.title: Encyclopedia: "Well, the suzerain was looking for..."
links.text: Well, the suzerain was looking for new markets for all the cocaine it was producing, and it settled on Safre...

links.title: Encyclopedia: "By introducing cocaine into Safre u..."
links.text: By introducing cocaine into Safre under exclusive contract, the suzerain created an extremely valuable captive market for an extremely *addictive* product.

links.title: You: "That's fucked up!"
links.text: That's fucked up!

links.title: Encyclopedia: "If you could somehow get the lieute..."
links.text: If you could somehow get the lieutenant's workers *addicted* to your cocaine, you could not only make them less productive, you would also force the lieutenant to *pay* you for your cocaine tokens *each turn*...

links.title: You: "Can you even *do* that?"
links.text: Can you even *do* that?

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Yes, you can. It's right there in t..."
links.text: Yes, you can. It's right there in the rules...

links.title: Authority: "Now's your chance. Show the lieuten..."
links.text: Now's your chance. Show the lieutenant what happens when he patronizes you.

links.title: You: "That's brilliant."
links.text: That's brilliant.

links.title: You: "What does that have to do with the..."
links.text: What does that have to do with the game?

links.title: You: "Ignore the thought."
links.text: Ignore the thought.

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "You've reached a critical strategic..."
links.text: You've reached a critical strategic juncture. How do you respond to the lieutenant's aggression?

links.title: You: ""Rock and roll, baby." (Go for the..."
links.text: "Rock and roll, baby." (Go for the contract.)

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "It takes several turns, but you slo..."
links.text: It takes several turns, but you slowly begin accumulating the cocaine necessary to complete the contract. When you do, it practically rains cardboard coins on your side...

links.title: Electrochemistry: "Feels good, doesn't it? But you kno..."
links.text: Feels good, doesn't it? But you know what would feel even *better*?

links.title: You: "Winning the game?"
links.text: Winning the game?

links.title: Electrochemistry: "*Drugs*. Specifically uppers. Speak..."
links.text: *Drugs*. Specifically uppers. Speaking of, aren't you supposed to be looking for some right about *now*?

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "While you daydream about speed, the..."
links.text: While you daydream about speed, the lieutenant has built himself a formidable economic engine of his own...

links.title: Electrochemistry: "*Drugs*. Specifically uppers. That'..."
links.text: *Drugs*. Specifically uppers. That's an itch... in the back of your neck and elsewhere...

links.title: Electrochemistry: "*Drugs*. Specifically uppers. You s..."
links.text: *Drugs*. Specifically uppers. You should find some the first chance you get.

links.title: You: "Solving the murder?"
links.text: Solving the murder?

links.title: You: "You're going to say 'drugs,' aren't..."
links.text: You're going to say 'drugs,' aren't you?

links.title: You: ""*Cha-CHING*, Kim!""
links.text: "*Cha-CHING*, Kim!"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "Despite your trash-talking, the lie..."
links.text: Despite your trash-talking, the lieutenant still has a formidable store of coins and resources...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "The endgame is upon you. How will y..."
links.text: The endgame is upon you. How will you spend the vast resources you've acquired for the glory of the suzerain?

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Flipping through the manual, you fi..."
links.text: Flipping through the manual, you find the most expensive structure in the game... the Revacholian *victory column*, worth *twelve victory points*. If you can successfully build it, victory will be all-but assured...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Alternatively, you could try launch..."
links.text: Alternatively, you could try launching a *trade war* to crush the lieutenant's economy, or you could blow all that money on a *public education system* for your worker tokens...

links.title: You: "Stack the coins in neat little pile..."
links.text: Stack the coins in neat little piles to annoy the lieutenant.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "Despite your conspicuous display of..."
links.text: Despite your conspicuous display of wealth, the lieutenant still has a formidable store of coins and resources...

links.title: You: "Give back to the workers."
links.text: Give back to the workers.

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Instead of focussing on amassing po..."
links.text: Instead of focussing on amassing points, you embark on a quixotic project to win the hearts of your worker tokens. After several turns you've unlocked advanced hobbies and health insurance. Your workers now produce an extra two resources per turn...

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""You do realize the game is called..."
links.text: "You do realize the game is called *Suzerainty* and not *Workers' Paradise*, right?"

links.title: You: ""I'm just trying to do right by the..."
links.text: "I'm just trying to do right by the people who actually generate the suzerain's wealth."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""I don't think the suzerain *cares*..."
links.text: "I don't think the suzerain *cares* much about the welfare of its workers. Here, watch this..."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant continues his strate..."
links.text: The lieutenant continues his strategy of aggressively producing apricots for export. He fulfils contract after contract, racking up ever more victory points...

links.title: You: ""I'm rejecting the arbitrary so-cal..."
links.text: "I'm rejecting the arbitrary so-called 'points' system developed by this game's politically compromised game designers."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Yes, you're *really* sticking it t..."
links.text: "Yes, you're *really* sticking it to the game designers, just like I'm about to stick it to *you*..."

links.title: You: ""What's the point of playing a game..."
links.text: "What's the point of playing a game if I can't make my own choices?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Well, *winning* is usually the poi..."
links.text: "Well, *winning* is usually the point of playing games. Here, watch this..."

links.title: You: ""Sorry, Kim, you're not going to li..."
links.text: "Sorry, Kim, you're not going to like this..." (Introduce the lieutenant's workers to cocaine.)

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Hrm..." The lieutenant's face goes..."
links.text: "Hrm..." The lieutenant's face goes stony as you take your turn. He does not appreciate you getting all his workers addicted to cocaine...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "With each passing turn you slowly b..."
links.text: With each passing turn you slowly bleed the lieutenant of coins as his own workers become less productive and more dependent on your magenta cocaine tokens.

links.title: Encyclopedia: "As a matter of historical fact, thi..."
links.text: As a matter of historical fact, this is almost *exactly* what happened in Safre. To this day, fully half of the former Safre Empire remains dependant on international aid in exchange for a steady supply of cheap produce.

links.title: You: ""Just like they did to Safre.""
links.text: "Just like they did to Safre."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""More or less," the lieutenant says..."
links.text: "More or less," the lieutenant says, but he's thinking less about matters of historical wrongdoing than how to get out of the jam you've put him in...

links.title: You: "Say nothing."
links.text: Say nothing.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "Realising victory is slipping away,..."
links.text: Realising victory is slipping away, the lieutenant launches a desperate gambit: *Protectionism*. By erecting tariffs on your cocaine he hopes to starve you out of the market at the risk of incurring the suzerain's disfavour...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "The endgame is upon you. Do you esc..."
links.text: The endgame is upon you. Do you escalate the *trade war* with the lieutenant in hopes of crushing him with your economic might?

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Or do you ignore his aggression and..."
links.text: Or do you ignore his aggression and focus on building the mighty *victory column* structure in Revachol herself?

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Alternatively, you could throw the..."
links.text: Alternatively, you could throw the whole game away by trying to build a *public education system* for the children of your workers...

links.title: You: "Attack the lieutenant and steal all..."
links.text: Attack the lieutenant and steal all his resources.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""You can't do that, detective," the..."
links.text: "You can't do that, detective," the lieutenant says as you move all of your pieces onto one of his territories.

links.title: You: ""I make the rules now.""
links.text: "I make the rules now."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""I'm not going to play with you if..."
links.text: "I'm not going to play with you if you're going to act like a child. Now come on, take your turn."

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "The lieutenant isn't joking. You'd..."
links.text: The lieutenant isn't joking. You'd better stop fooling around.

links.title: You: ""What do you mean? I just did.""
links.text: "What do you mean? I just did."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""This is a game of *economic* strat..."
links.text: "This is a game of *economic* strategy. You can't directly attack the other players. You'll have to do something else."

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "It's true. Had you read the rules m..."
links.text: It's true. Had you read the rules more carefully this would have been abundantly clear.

links.title: You: ""So what *can* I do?""
links.text: "So what *can* I do?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Well, I suppose you could try fulf..."
links.text: "Well, I suppose you could try fulfilling some contracts, or you might try to relocate your workers. There are any number of strategies open to you."

links.title: You: ""I'm bored with this. Let's do some..."
links.text: "I'm bored with this. Let's do something else."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Are you sure?" The lieutenant look..."
links.text: "Are you sure?" The lieutenant looks a little disappointed. "It's going to take a while to set everything up again."

links.title: You: "Put the game away."
links.text: Put the game away.

links.title: You: "Keep playing."
links.text: Keep playing.

links.title: You: ""Kim, what should I do?""
links.text: "Kim, what should I do?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""That's up to you, detective. But r..."
links.text: "That's up to you, detective. But remember, the objective of the game is to earn victory points for the suzerain..."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""You should probably pick one strat..."
links.text: "You should probably pick one strategy and stick to it. Trying to do a little of everything is usually a bad idea."

links.title: You: ""But what about the workers?""
links.text: "But what about the workers?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""The workers are just there to prod..."
links.text: "The workers are just there to produce raw resources. You're not supposed to worry about them too much."

links.title: Volition: "The lieutenant assumes you're playi..."
links.text: The lieutenant assumes you're playing by the rules as written. But what's the point of playing if you can't make your own choices?

links.title: You: ""Why don't we say 'screw the suzera..."
links.text: "Why don't we say 'screw the suzerain' and keep it all for ourselves?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Because the way you earn points is..."
links.text: "Because the way you earn points is by pleasing the suzerain, and the player with the most points wins the game."

links.title: You: ""I'm bored with this. Let's finish..."
links.text: "I'm bored with this. Let's finish the game later."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Are you sure?" The lieutenant look..."
links.text: "Are you sure?" The lieutenant looks a little disappointed. "It's going to take a while to set everything up again."

links.title: You: "Put the game away."
links.text: Put the game away.

links.title: You: "Keep playing."
links.text: Keep playing.

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "It's your move."
links.text: It's your move.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Hmmm... this doesn't look right to..."
links.text: "Hmmm... this doesn't look right to me. I think we need to start over, unfortunately..."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant goes first. He draws..."
links.text: The lieutenant goes first. He draws a contract card and moves several of his workers to the Safre territory of the board and the others to the Semenine Islands...

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Alright, detective. Your turn.""
links.text: "Alright, detective. Your turn."

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "You have a few options available to..."
links.text: You have a few options available to you: Will you try to fulfil contracts right away or rearrange your workers to maximize production on future turns?

links.title: Reaction Speed: "Remember what the rulebook said! Yo..."
links.text: Remember what the rulebook said! You'll want to choose a strategy early on and stay committed to it.

links.title: You: "Try to fulfil a contract."
links.text: Try to fulfil a contract.

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "You draw a contract card offering a..."
links.text: You draw a contract card offering a number of coins in exchange for archaeological treasures...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "You place all of your workers on th..."
links.text: You place all of your workers on the Ile Marat territory. On your next turn you produce six units of archaeological treasure and fulfil the contract for a handful of coins.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Not bad, detective.""
links.text: "Not bad, detective."

links.title: Rhetoric: "But not good enough, the lieutenant..."
links.text: But not good enough, the lieutenant seems to be saying.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "As he completes his own contract ca..."
links.text: As he completes his own contract card, the lieutenant is rewarded with four coins and a round wooden token that he places in the centre of the board...

links.title: You: "Let your workers rest for a while."
links.text: Let your workers rest for a while.

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "What? It's the very beginning of th..."
links.text: What? It's the very beginning of the game. Your workers haven't even done any work yet.

links.title: You: "Let them rest anyway."
links.text: Let them rest anyway.

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "There's no concept of *rest* in Suz..."
links.text: There's no concept of *rest* in Suzerainty. Workers have to work. You produce a handful of archaeological treasures and a smattering of other resources.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "Meanwhile, the lieutenant spends tw..."
links.text: Meanwhile, the lieutenant spends two of his sugar and one of his apricot tokens to complete his contract card. He is rewarded with four coins and a round wooden token that he places in the centre of the board...

links.title: You: "Okay, make them work a little, but..."
links.text: Okay, make them work a little, but not *too* much.

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "That's more like it. You produce a..."
links.text: That's more like it. You produce a handful of archaeological treasures and a smattering of other resources.

links.title: You: "Just do whatever Kim did."
links.text: Just do whatever Kim did.

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "You move a few of your workers to t..."
links.text: You move a few of your workers to the Ile Marat section of the board and several others to Supramundi and Saramiriza. Soon you have several units of archaeological treasure and cocaine.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""An aggressive opening, detective,"..."
links.text: "An aggressive opening, detective," the lieutenant says, appearing to relish the challenge.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "In response, the lieutenant spends..."
links.text: In response, the lieutenant spends two of his sugar and one of his apricot tokens to complete his contract card. He is rewarded with four coins and a round wooden token that he places in the centre of the board...

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""That's a market. It's worth *two v..."
links.text: "That's a market. It's worth *two victory points*."

links.title: You: ""Hey, why don't I get one of those?""
links.text: "Hey, why don't I get one of those?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Don't worry, it was mostly just lu..."
links.text: "Don't worry, it was mostly just luck. You'll earn some points soon enough."

links.title: Authority: "What is that patronizing tone? You'..."
links.text: What is that patronizing tone? You're one of the suzerain's trusted administrators! You may need to put the lieutenant in his place...

links.title: You: ""I'm not even sure what points *are..."
links.text: "I'm not even sure what points *are* -- that's part of the problem."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Points are nothing. They don't exi..."
links.text: "Points are nothing. They don't exist. They're just an arbitrary convention that games use to reward or punish players for certain behaviours."

links.title: Conceptualization: "If points are really *arbitrary*, a..."
links.text: If points are really *arbitrary*, as the lieutenant says, what's to stop you from playing the game the way *you* want?

links.title: You: ""Who came up with such a concept?""
links.text: "Who came up with such a concept?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Game designers, I imagine.""
links.text: "Game designers, I imagine."

links.title: You: ""Am *I* getting points right now?"..."
links.text: "Am *I* getting points right now?" (Look around.)

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant shrugs. "There are s..."
links.text: The lieutenant shrugs. "There are some *paranoid* types who believe the Moralintern keeps detailed score sheets for everyone in the Rel Belt, but that's obviously nonsense..."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Otherwise, no. There are no points..."
links.text: "Otherwise, no. There are no points, just your actions and the consequences of those actions."

links.title: Authority: "Just like there are no *honour poin..."
links.text: Just like there are no *honour points*. None whatsoever.

links.title: You: ""What's the... Moralintern?""
links.text: "What's the... Moralintern?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""That's a subject for another time...."
links.text: "That's a subject for another time. All you need to know is that they're a powerful transnational organization, of which the *Coalition* and by extension the RCM are but one small piece."

links.title: You: ""That's reassuring.""
links.text: "That's reassuring."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""That's just the way it is." The li..."
links.text: "That's just the way it is." The lieutenant doesn't seem to find much value in dwelling on the subject...

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Now, I believe it's your turn...""
links.text: "Now, I believe it's your turn..."

links.title: You: ""That's terrifying.""
links.text: "That's terrifying."

links.title: You: ""Oh, that makes sense.""
links.text: "Oh, that makes sense."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant nods. "Now, I believ..."
links.text: The lieutenant nods. "Now, I believe it's your turn..."

links.title: You: ""Kim, can I do my first turn over?..."
links.text: "Kim, can I do my first turn over? I think I messed up."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Come on, detective, don't be a spo..."
links.text: "Come on, detective, don't be a spoil sport. You'll have plenty of chances to earn your own points."

links.title: Authority: "What is that patronizing tone? Some..."
links.text: What is that patronizing tone? Someone needs to put the lieutenant in his place.

links.title: You: "Glower silently."
links.text: Glower silently.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant returns your baleful..."
links.text: The lieutenant returns your baleful look with a satisfied grin.

links.title: Composure: "C'mon, is that your game face? You'..."
links.text: C'mon, is that your game face? You're practically broadcasting your position to the lieutenant with that expression.

links.title: You: "Convince Kim to play with you."
links.text: Convince Kim to play with you.

links.title: Suggestion: "What is detective work if not an el..."
links.text: What is detective work if not an elaborate game? You need logical inference, attention to detail, the ability to analyse your opponents' motives...

links.title: You: ""Come on, it might help us think of..."
links.text: "Come on, it might help us think of more creative solutions to the case."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Hmmm, I do feel like my thinking h..."
links.text: "Hmmm, I do feel like my thinking has become somewhat *rigid*. Maybe a little diversion to keep the mind limber is just what's in order..."

links.title: Suggestion: "See? He's doing the hard work himse..."
links.text: See? He's doing the hard work himself. All he needed was a little nudge...

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Alright, you've convinced me. How..."
links.text: "Alright, you've convinced me. How do we play?"

links.title: You: ""I don't know, let's wing it.""
links.text: "I don't know, let's wing it."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""I see you bring the same *unorthod..."
links.text: "I see you bring the same *unorthodox technique* to playing board games as you do to detective work..."

links.title: You: ""Hmm, we should probably read the r..."
links.text: "Hmm, we should probably read the rules, huh?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""When I thrash you I want to make s..."
links.text: "When I thrash you I want to make sure it's *by the book*."

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "The lieutenant flips through the ma..."
links.text: The lieutenant flips through the manual more quickly than you're able to keep up with. Then you each take your bags of tokens and counters and unfold the board between you...

links.title: You: ""I read the rules already, I'll sho..."
links.text: "I read the rules already, I'll show you..."

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "You explain the basic set up proced..."
links.text: You explain the basic set up procedures to the lieutenant, who seems to be a quick study. You each take your bags of tokens and counters and unfold the board between you...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "In the centre is the crown of Revac..."
links.text: In the centre is the crown of Revachol. Radiating outward are her colourful vassals, each one supplying some raw material desired by the suzerain...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Apricots from Safre, archaeological..."
links.text: Apricots from Safre, archaeological treasures from Ile Marat, sugar from the Semenine Islands, and magenta cocaine from Supramundi and Saramiriza...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "There's also a neat little log to k..."
links.text: There's also a neat little log to keep track of your progress, in case you need to put the game away and return to it later...

links.title: Suggestion: "At this point, plain badgering may..."
links.text: At this point, plain badgering may be your best bet.

links.title: You: ""Come on, Kim, *puh-leeeeeze*.""
links.text: "Come on, Kim, *puh-leeeeeze*."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant sighs so hard for a..."
links.text: The lieutenant sighs so hard for a moment it seems like he may asphyxiate...

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Alright, detective, you win. How d..."
links.text: "Alright, detective, you win. How do we play this game?"

links.title: Suggestion: "Have you tried... goading him?"
links.text: Have you tried... goading him?

links.title: You: ""You just chickening out because yo..."
links.text: "You just chickening out because you know I'd crush your ass."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant scoffs. "In your *dr..."
links.text: The lieutenant scoffs. "In your *dreams*, maybe. I've thrashed my share of trash-talkers before. Now come on, let's put childish things aside."

links.title: Empathy: "Ignore the mock umbrage. Now he wan..."
links.text: Ignore the mock umbrage. Now he wants to prove it to you.

links.title: Suggestion: "What, does the lieutenant hate fun?..."
links.text: What, does the lieutenant hate fun? Is he the *fun* police?

links.title: You: ""Who died and made you the fun poli..."
links.text: "Who died and made you the fun police?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant gives you a sour loo..."
links.text: The lieutenant gives you a sour look. He may or may not hate fun, but either way he does not appreciate your attitude...

links.title: You: "[Put the game away.]"
links.text: [Put the game away.]

dialogueTree.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "In your hands you hold a brand new..."
dialogueTree.text: In your hands you hold a brand new copy of the game 'Suzerainty'. It's snugly wrapped in a skin of plastic...

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "The cover features a charming illus..."
links.text: The cover features a charming illustration depicting a mass of grinning labourers loading goods onto a ship while a richly dressed administrator oversees their work.

links.title: Encyclopedia: "The exact location and time period..."
links.text: The exact location and time period are left deliberately vague, but it's clearly meant to represent the economic relationship between the Revacholian Suzerainty and its many vassals.

links.title: You: "Shake the box."
links.text: Shake the box.

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "The box has a nice heft to it. You..."
links.text: The box has a nice heft to it. You hear the rattle of individual wooden tokens and feel their weight shifting back and forth...

links.title: Inland Empire: "What treasures wait in store for yo..."
links.text: What treasures wait in store for you?

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Even before you open it, you can te..."
links.text: Even before you open it, you can tell that this will be a meaty game of grand strategy and complex player interactions.

links.title: You: "Remove the plastic wrap."
links.text: Remove the plastic wrap.

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "The plastic wrap rips off as easily..."
links.text: The plastic wrap rips off as easily as a bodice in a tawdry historical romance.

links.title: You: "Open the box."
links.text: Open the box.

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "There's a hiss as the lid slides of..."
links.text: There's a hiss as the lid slides off. Inside you find a thick, full-colour rulebook and more than a dozen pouches of various wooden components.

links.title: Perception (Smell): "Ahhh! Savour that new board game sm..."
links.text: Ahhh! Savour that new board game smell! A mix of wood, paper, and ink, all wrapped in the sweet must of cardboard.

links.title: You: "[Leave it perfect and undisturbed.]"
links.text: [Leave it perfect and undisturbed.]

links.title: Suzerainty: The Board Game: "Good thinking. It could be a collec..."
links.text: Good thinking. It could be a collectible some day.
